books.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:1
verses.text: The choice of Gideon was a figure of our Lord's Incarnation, the sacrifice of a kid, of the satisfaction for sins in the body of Christ; that of the bullock, of the abolition of profane rites; and in the three hundred soldiers was a type of the future redemption through the cross.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:2
verses.text: The seeking of various signs by Gideon was also a mystery, for by the dryness and moistening of the fleece was signified the falling away of the Jews and the calling of the Gentiles, by the water received in a basin the washing of the apostles' feet.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:3
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:4
verses.text: Ambrose prays that his own pollution may be washed away, and praises the loving-kindness of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:5
verses.text: The same water sent forth by the Son of God effects marvellous conversions; it cannot, however, be sent by any other, since it is the pouring forth of the Holy Spirit, Who is subject to no external power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:6
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:7
verses.text: When Jerubbaal, as we read, was beating out wheat under an oak, he received a message from God in order that he might bring the people of God from the power of strangers into liberty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:8
verses.text: Nor is it a matter of wonder if he was chosen for grace, seeing that even then, being appointed under the shadow of the holy cross and of the adorable Wisdom in the predestined mystery of the future Incarnation, he was bringing forth the visible grains of the fruitful corn from their hiding places, and was [mystically] separating the elect of the saints from the refuse of the empty chaff.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:9
verses.text: For these elect, as though trained with the rod of truth, laying aside the superfluities of the old man together with his deeds, are gathered in the Church as in a winepress.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:10
verses.text: For the Church is the winepress of the eternal fountain, since from her wells forth the juice of the heavenly Vine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:11
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:12
verses.text: And Gideon, moved by that message, when he heard that, though thousands of the people failed, God would deliver His own from their enemies by means of one man, offered a kid, and according to the word of the Angel, laid its flesh and the unleavened cakes upon the rock, and poured the broth upon them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:13
verses.text: And as soon as the Angel touched them with the end of the staff which he bore, fire burst forth out of the rock, and so the sacrifice which he was offering was consumed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:14
verses.text: By which it seems clear that that rock was a figure of the Body of Christ, for it is written: "They drank of that rock that followed them, and that rock was Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:15
verses.text: Which certainly refers not to His Godhead, but to His Flesh, which watered the hearts of the thirsting people with the perpetual stream of His Blood.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:16
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:17
verses.text: Even at that time was it declared in a mystery that the Lord Jesus in His Flesh would, when crucified, do away the sins of the whole world, and not only the deeds of the body, but the desires of the soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:18
verses.text: For the flesh of the kid refers to sins of deed, the broth to the enticements of desire as it is written: "For the people lusted an evil lust, and said, Who shall give us flesh to eat?" That the Angel then stretched forth his staff, and touched the rock, from which fire went out, shows that the Flesh of the Lord, being filled with the Divine Spirit, would burn away all the sins of human frailty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:19
verses.text: Wherefore, also, the Lord says: "I am come to send fire upon the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:20
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:21
verses.text: Then the man, instructed and foreknowing what was to be, observes the heavenly mysteries, and therefore, according to the warning, slew the bullock destined by his father to idols, and himself offered to God another bullock seven years old.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:22
verses.text: By doing which he most plainly showed that after the coming of the Lord all Gentile sacrifices should be done away, and that only the sacrifice of the Lord's passion should be offered for the redemption of the people.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:23
verses.text: For that bullock was, in a type, Christ, in Whom, as Esaias said, dwelt the fulness of the seven gifts of the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:24
verses.text: This bullock Abraham also offered when he saw the day of the Lord and was glad.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:25
verses.text: He it is Who was offered at one time in the type of a kid, at another in that of a sheep, at another in that of a bullock.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:26
verses.text: Of a kid, because He is a sacrifice for sin; of a sheep, because He is an unresisting victim; of a bullock, because He is a victim without blemish.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:27
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:28
verses.text: Holy Gideon then saw the mystery beforehand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:29
verses.text: Next he chose out three hundred for the battle, so as to show that the world should be freed from the incursion of worse enemies, not by the multitude of their number, but by the mystery of the cross.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:30
verses.text: And yet, though he was brave and faithful, he asked of the Lord yet fuller proofs of future victory, saying: "If Thou wilt save Israel by mine hand, O Lord, as Thou hast said, behold I will put a fleece of wool on the threshing-floor, and if there shall be dew on the fleece and dryness on all the ground, I shall know that Thou wilt deliver the people by my hand according to Thy promise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:31
verses.text: And it was so".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:32
verses.text: Afterwards he asked in addition that dew should descend on all the earth and dryness be on the fleece.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:33
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:34
verses.text: Some one perhaps will enquire whether he does not seem to have been wanting in faith, seeing that after being instructed by many signs he asked still more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:35
verses.text: But how can he seem to have asked as if doubting or wanting in faith, who was speaking in mysteries? He was not then doubtful, but careful that we should not doubt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:36
verses.text: For how could he be doubtful whose prayer was effectual? And how could he have begun the battle without fear, unless he had understood the message of God? for the dew on the fleece signified the faith among the Jews, because the words of God come down like the dew.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:37
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:38
verses.text: So when the whole world was parched with the drought of Gentile superstition, then came that dew of the heavenly visits on the fleece.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:39
verses.text: But after that the lost sheep of the house of Israel (whom I think that the figure of the Jewish fleece shadowed forth), after that those sheep, I say, "had refused the fountain of living water," the dew of moistening faith dried up in the breasts of the Jews, and that divine Fountain turned away its course to the hearts of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:40
verses.text: Whence it has come to pass that now the whole world is moistened with the dew of faith, but the Jews have lost their prophets and counsellors.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:41
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:42
verses.text: Nor is it strange that they should suffer the drought of unbelief, whom the Lord deprived of the fertilising of the shower of prophecy, saying: "I will command My clouds that they rain not upon that vineyard".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:43
verses.text: For there is a health-giving shower of salutary grace, as David also said: "He came down like rain upon a fleece, and like drops that drop upon the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:44
verses.text: The divine Scriptures promised us this rain upon the whole earth, to water the world with the dew of the Divine Spirit at the coming of the Saviour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:45
verses.text: The Lord, then, has now come, and the rain has come; the Lord has come bringing the heavenly drops with Him, and so now we drink, who before were thirsty, and with an interior draught drink in that Divine Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:46
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:47
verses.text: Holy Gideon, then, foresaw this, that the nations of the Gentiles also would drink by the reception of faith, and therefore he enquired more diligently, for the caution of the saints is necessary.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:48
verses.text: Insomuch that also Joshua the son of Nun, when he saw the captain of the heavenly host, enquired: "Art thou for us, or for our adversaries?" lest, perchance, he might be deceived by some stratagem of the adversary.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:49
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:50
verses.text: Nor was it without a reason that he put the fleece neither in a field nor in a meadow, but in a threshing-floor, where is the harvest of the wheat: "For the harvest is plenteous, but the labourers are few;" because that, through faith in the Lord, there was about to be a harvest fruitful in virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:51
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:52
verses.text: Nor, again, was it without a reason that he dried the fleece of the Jews, and put the dew from it into a basin, so that it was filled with water, yet he did not himself wash his feet in that dew.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:53
verses.text: The prerogative of so great a mystery was to be given to another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:54
verses.text: He was being waited for Who alone could wash away the filth of all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:55
verses.text: Gideon was not great enough to claim this mystery for himself, but "the Son of Man  came not to be ministered unto, but to minister".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:56
verses.text: Let us, then, recognize in Whom these mysteries are seen to be accomplished.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:57
verses.text: Not in holy Gideon, for they were still at their commencement.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:58
verses.text: Therefore the Gentiles were surpassed, for dryness was still upon the Gentiles, and therefore did Israel surpass them, for then did the dew remain on the fleece.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:59
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:60
verses.text: Let us come now to the Gospel of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:61
verses.text: I find the Lord stripping Himself of His garments, and girding Himself with a towel, pouring water into a basin, and washing the disciples' feet.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:62
verses.text: That heavenly dew was this water, this was foretold, namely, that the Lord Jesus Christ would wash the feet of His disciples in that heavenly dew.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:63
verses.text: And now let the feet of our minds be stretched out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:64
verses.text: The Lord Jesus wills also to wash our feet, for He says, not to Peter alone, but to each of the faithful: "If I wash not thy feet thou wilt have no part with Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:65
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:66
verses.text: Come, then, Lord Jesus, put off Thy garments, which Thou didst put on for my sake; be Thou stripped that Thou mayest clothe us with Thy mercy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:67
verses.text: Gird Thyself for our sakes with a towel, that Thou mayest gird us with Thy gift of immortality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:68
verses.text: Pour water into the basin, wash not only our feet but also the head, and not only of the body, but also the footsteps of the soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:69
verses.text: I wish to put off all the filth of our frailty, so that I also may say: "By night I have put off my coat, how shall I put it on? I have washed my feet, how shall I defile them?"  14.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:70
verses.text: How great is that excellence! As a servant, Thou dost wash the feet of Thy disciples; as God, Thou sendest dew from heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:71
verses.text: Nor dost Thou wash the feet only, but also invitest us to sit down with Thee, and by the example of Thy dignity dost exhort us, saying: "Ye call Me Master and Lord, and ye do well, for so I am.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:72
verses.text: If, then, I the Lord and Master have washed your feet, ye ought also to wash one another's feet".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:73
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:74
verses.text: I, then, wish also myself to wash the feet of my brethren, I wish to fulfil the commandment of my Lord, I will not be ashamed in myself, nor disdain what He Himself did first.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:75
verses.text: Good is the mystery of humility, because while washing the pollutions of others I wash away my own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:76
verses.text: But all were not able to exhaust this mystery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:77
verses.text: Abraham was, indeed, willing to wash feet, but because of a feeling of hospitality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:78
verses.text: Gideon, too, was willing to wash the feet of the Angel of the Lord who appeared to him, but his willingness was confined to one; he was willing as one who would do a service, not as one who would confer fellowship with himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:79
verses.text: This is a great mystery which no one knew.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:80
verses.text: Lastly, the Lord said to Peter: "What I do thou knowest not now, but shalt know hereafter".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:81
verses.text: This, I say, is a divine mystery which even they who wash will enquire into.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:82
verses.text: It is not, then, the simple water of the heavenly mystery whereby we attain to be found worthy of having part with Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:83
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:84
verses.text: There is also a certain water which we put into the basin of our soul, water from the fleece and from the Book of Judges; water, too, from the Book of Psalms.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:85
verses.text: It is the water of the message from heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:86
verses.text: Let, then, this water, O Lord Jesus, come into my soul, into my flesh, that through the moisture of this rain the valleys of our minds and the fields of our hearts may grow green.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:87
verses.text: May the drops from Thee come upon me, shedding forth grace and immortality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:88
verses.text: Wash the steps of my mind that I may not sin again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:89
verses.text: Wash the heel of my soul, that I may be able to efface the curse, that I feel not the serpent's bite on the foot of my soul, but, as Thou Thyself hast bidden those who follow Thee, may tread on serpents and scorpions with uninjured foot.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:90
verses.text: Thou hast redeemed the world, redeem the soul of a single sinner.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:91
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:92
verses.text: This is the special excellence of Thy loving-kindness, wherewith Thou hast redeemed the whole world one by one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:93
verses.text: Elijah was sent to one widow; Elisha cleansed one; Thou, O Lord Jesus, hast at this day cleansed a thousand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:94
verses.text: How many in the city of Rome, how many at Alexandria, how many at Antioch, how many also at Constantinople! For even Constantinople has received the word of God, and has received evident proofs of Thy judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:95
verses.text: For so long as she cherished the Arians' poison in her bosom, disquieted by neighbouring wars, she echoed with hostile arms around.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:96
verses.text: But so soon as she rejected those who were  alien from the faith she received as a suppliant the enemy himself, the judge of kings, whom she had always been wont to fear, she buried him when dead, and retains him entombed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:97
verses.text: How many, then, hast Thou cleansed at Constantinople, how many, lastly, at this day in the whole world!  18.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:98
verses.text: Damasus cleansed not, Peter cleansed not, Ambrose cleansed not, Gregory cleansed not; for ours is the ministry, but the sacraments are Thine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:99
verses.text: For it is not in man's power to confer what is divine, but it is, O Lord, Thy gift and that of the Father, as Thou hast spoken by the prophets, saying: "I will pour out of My Spirit upon all flesh, and their sons and their daughters shall prophesy".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:100
verses.text: This is that typical dew from heaven, this is that gracious rain, as we read: "A gracious rain, dividing for His inheritance".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:101
verses.text: For the Holy Spirit is not subject to any foreign power or law, but is the Arbiter of His own freedom, dividing all things according to the decision of His own will, to each, as we read, severally as He wills.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:102
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:103
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:104
verses.text: Ambrose commences his argument by complimenting the Emperor, both for his faith and for the restitution of the Basilica to the Church; then having urged that his opponents, if they affirm that the Holy Spirit is not a servant, cannot deny Him to be above all, adds that the same Spirit, when He said, "All things serve Thee," showed plainly that He was distinct from creatures; which point he also establishes by other evidence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:105
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:106
verses.text: The Holy Spirit, then, is not amongst but above all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:107
verses.text: For (since you, most merciful Emperor, are so fully instructed concerning the Son of God as to be able yourself to teach others) I will not detain you longer, as you desire and claim to be told something more exactly [concerning Him], especially since you lately showed yourself to be so pleased by an argument of this nature, as to command the Basilica to be restored to the Church without any one urging you.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:108
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:109
verses.text: So, then, we have received the grace of your faith and the reward of our own; for we cannot say otherwise than that it was of the grace of the Holy Spirit, that when all were unconscious of it, you suddenly restored the Basilica.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:110
verses.text: This is the gift, I say, this the work of the Holy Spirit, Who indeed was at that time preached by us, but was working in you.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:111
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:112
verses.text: And I do not regret the losses of the previous time, since the sequestration of that Basilica resulted in the gain of a sort of usury.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:113
verses.text: For you sequestrated the Basilica, that you might give proof of your faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:114
verses.text: And so your piety fulfilled its intention, which had sequestered that it might give proof, and so gave proof as to restore.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:115
verses.text: I did not lose the fruit, and I have your judgment, and it has been made clear to all that, with a certain diversity of action, there was in you no diversity of opinion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:116
verses.text: It was made clear, I say, to all, that it was not of yourself that you sequestrated, that it was of yourself when you restored it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:117
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:118
verses.text: Now let us establish by evidence what we have said.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:119
verses.text: The first point in the discussion is that all things serve.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:120
verses.text: Now it is clear that all things serve, since it is written: "All things serve Thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:121
verses.text: This the Spirit said through the prophet.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:122
verses.text: He did not say, We serve, but, "serve Thee," that you might believe that He Himself is excepted from serving.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:123
verses.text: So, then, since all things serve, and the Spirit does not serve, the Holy Spirit is certainly not included amongst all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:124
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:125
verses.text: For if we say that the Holy Spirit is included amongst all things, certainly when we read that the Spirit searches the deep things of God, we deny that God the Father is over all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:126
verses.text: For since the Spirit is of God, and is the Spirit of His mouth, how can we say that the Holy Spirit is included amongst all things, seeing that God, Whose is the Spirit, is over all, possessing certainly fulness of perfection and perfect power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:127
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:128
verses.text: But lest the objectors should think that the Apostle was in error, let them learn whom he followed as his authority for his belief.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:129
verses.text: The Lord said in the Gospel: "When the Paraclete is come, Whom I will send to you from My Father, even the Spirit of Truth which proceedeth from the Father, He shall bear witness of Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:130
verses.text: So the Holy Spirit both proceeds from the Father, and bears witness of the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:131
verses.text: For the witness Who is both faithful and true bears witness of the Father, than which witness nothing is more full for the expression of the Divine Majesty, nothing more clear as to the Unity of the Divine Power,  since the Spirit has the same knowledge as the Son, Who is the witness and inseparable sharer of the Father's secrets.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:132
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:133
verses.text: He excludes, then, the fellowship and number of creatures from the knowledge of God, but by not excluding the Holy Spirit, He shows that He is not of the fellowship of creatures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:134
verses.text: So that the passage which is read in the Gospel: "For no man hath seen God at any time, save the Only-begotten Son Who is in the bosom of the Father He hath declared Him," also pertains to the exclusion of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:135
verses.text: For how has He not seen God Who searches even the deep things of God? How has He not seen God Who knows the things which are of God? How has He not seen God Who is of God? So, since it is laid down that no one has seen God at any time, whereas the Holy Spirit has seen Him, clearly the Holy Spirit is excepted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 1:136
verses.text: He, then, is above all Who is excluded from all.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:2
verses.text: The words, "All things were made by Him," are not a proof that the Holy Spirit is included amongst all things, since He was not made.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:3
verses.text: For otherwise it could be proved by other passages that the Son, and even the Father Himself, must be numbered amongst all things, which would be similar irreverence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:4
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:5
verses.text: This seems, gracious Emperor, to be a full account of our right feeling, but to the impious it does not seem so.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:6
verses.text: Observe what they are striving after.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:7
verses.text: For the heretics are wont to say that the Holy Spirit is to be reckoned amongst all things, because it is written of God the Son: "All things were made by Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:8
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:9
verses.text: How utterly confused is a course of argument which does not hold to the truth, and is involved in an inverted order of statements.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:10
verses.text: For this argument would be of value for the statement that the Holy Spirit is amongst all things, if they proved that He was made.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:11
verses.text: For Scripture says that all things which were made were made by the Son; but since we are not taught that the Holy Spirit was made, He certainly cannot be proved to be amongst all things Who was neither made as all things are, nor created.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:12
verses.text: To me this testimony is of use for establishing each point; firstly, that He is proved to be above all things, because He was not made; and secondly, that because He is above all things, He is seen not to have been made, and is not to be numbered amongst those things which were made.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:13
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:14
verses.text: But if any one, because the Evangelist stated that all things were made by the Word, making no exception of the Holy Spirit (although the Spirit of God speaking in John said: "All things were made by Him," and said not we were all things which were made; whilst the Lord Himself distinctly showed that the Spirit of God spoke in the Evangelists, saying, "For it will not be you that speak, but the Spirit of your Father that speaketh in you"), yet if any one, as I said, does not except the Holy Spirit in this place, but numbers Him amongst all, he consequently does not except the Son of God in that passage where the Apostle says: "Yet to us there is one God the Father, of Whom are all things, and we by Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:15
verses.text: But that he may know that the Son is not amongst all things, let him read what follows, for when he says: "And one Lord Jesus Christ, by Whom are all things," he certainly excepts the Son of God from all, who also excepted the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:16
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:17
verses.text: But it is equal irreverence to detract from the dignity of the Father, or the Son, or the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:18
verses.text: For he believes not in the Father who does not believe in the Son, nor does he believe in the Son of God who does not believe in the Spirit, nor can faith stand without the rule of truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:19
verses.text: For he who has begun to deny the oneness of power in the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit certainly cannot prove his divided faith in points where there is no division.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:20
verses.text: So, then, since complete piety is to believe rightly, so complete impiety is to believe wrongly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:21
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:22
verses.text: Therefore they who think that the Holy Spirit ought to be numbered amongst all things, because they read that all things were made by the Son, must needs also think that the Son is to be numbered amongst all things, because they read: "All things are of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:23
verses.text: But, consequently, they also do not separate the Father from all things, who do not separate the Son from all creatures, since, as all things are of the Father, so, too, all things are by the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 2:24
verses.text: And the Apostle, because of his foresight in the Spirit, used this very expression, lest he should seem to the impious who had heard that the Son had said, "That which My Father hath given Me is greater than all," to have included the Son amongst all.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:2
verses.text: The statement of the Apostle, that all things are of the Father by the Son, does not separate the Spirit from Their company, since what is referred to one Person is also attributed to each.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:3
verses.text: So those baptized in the Name of Christ are held to be baptized in the Name of the Father and of the Holy Spirit, if, that is, there is belief in the Three Persons, otherwise the baptism will be null.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:4
verses.text: This also applies to baptism in the Name of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:5
verses.text: If because of one passage the Holy Spirit is separated from the Father and the Son, it will necessarily follow from other passages that the Father will be subordinated to the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:6
verses.text: The Son is worshipped by angels, not by the Spirit, for the latter is His witness, not His servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:7
verses.text: Where the Son is spoken of as being before all, it is to be understood of creatures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:8
verses.text: The great dignity of the Holy Spirit is proved by the absence of forgiveness for the sin against Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:9
verses.text: How it is that such sin cannot be forgiven, and how the Spirit is one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:10
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:11
verses.text: But perhaps some one may say that there was a reason why the writer said that all things were of the Father, and all things through the Son, but made no mention of the Holy Spirit, and would obtain the foundation of an argument from this.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:12
verses.text: But if he persists in his perverse interpretation, in how many passages will he find the power of the Holy Spirit asserted, in which Scripture has stated nothing concerning either the Father or the Son, but has left it to be understood?  40.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:13
verses.text: Where, then, the grace of the Spirit is asserted, is that of God the Father or of the Only-begotten Son denied? By no means; for as the Father is in the Son, and the Son in the Father, so, too, "the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit, Who hath been given us".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:14
verses.text: And as he who is blessed in Christ is blessed in the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit, because the Name is one and the Power one; so, too, when any divine operation, whether of the Father, or of the Son, or of the Holy Spirit, is treated of, it is not referred only to the Holy Spirit, but also to the Father and the Son, and not only to the Father, but also to the Son and the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:15
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:16
verses.text: Then, too, the Ethiopian eunuch of Queen Candace, when baptized in Christ, obtained the fulness of the sacrament.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:17
verses.text: And they who said that they knew not of any Holy Spirit, although they said that they had been baptized with John's baptism, were baptized afterwards, because John baptized for the remission of sins in the Name of the coming Jesus, not in his own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:18
verses.text: And so they knew not the Spirit, because in the form in which John baptized they had not received baptism in the Name of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:19
verses.text: For John, though he did not baptize in the Spirit, nevertheless preached Christ and the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:20
verses.text: And then, when he was questioned whether he were perchance himself the Christ, he answered: "I baptize you with water, but a stronger than I shall come, Whose shoes I am not worthy to bear, He shall baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:21
verses.text: They therefore, because they had been baptized neither in the Name of Christ nor with faith in the Holy Spirit, could not receive the sacrament of baptism.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:22
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:23
verses.text: So they were baptized in the Name of Jesus Christ, and baptism was not repeated in their case, but administered differently, for there is but one baptism.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:24
verses.text: But where there is not the complete sacrament of baptism, there is not considered to be a commencement nor any kind of baptism.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:25
verses.text: But baptism is complete if one confess the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:26
verses.text: If you deny One you overthrow the whole.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:27
verses.text: And just as if you mention in words One only, either the Father, or the Son, or the Holy Spirit, and in your belief do not deny either the Father, the Son, or the Holy Spirit, the mystery of the faith is complete, so, too, although you name the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, and lessen the power of either the Father, the Son, or the Holy Spirit, the whole mystery is made empty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:28
verses.text: And, lastly, they who had said: "We have not heard if there be any Holy Spirit, were baptized afterwards in the Name of the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:29
verses.text: And this was an additional abundance of grace, for now through Paul's preaching they knew the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:30
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:31
verses.text: Nor ought it to seem opposed to this, that although subsequently mention is not made of the Spirit, He is yet believed in, and what had not been mentioned in words is expressed in belief.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:32
verses.text: For when it is said, "In the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ," the mystery is complete through the oneness of the Name, and the Spirit is not separated  from the baptism of Christ, since John baptized unto repentance, Christ in the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:33
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:34
verses.text: Let us now consider whether as we read that the sacrament of baptism in the Name of Christ was complete, so, too, when the Holy Spirit alone is named, anything is wanting to the completeness of the mystery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:35
verses.text: Let us follow out the argument that he who has named One has signified the Trinity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:36
verses.text: If you name Christ, you imply both God the Father by Whom the Son was anointed, and the Son Himself Who was anointed, and the Holy Spirit with Whom He was anointed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:37
verses.text: For it is written: "This Jesus of Nazareth, Whom God anointed with the Holy Spirit".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:38
verses.text: And if you name the Father, you denote equally His Son and the Spirit of His mouth, if, that is, you apprehend it in your heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:39
verses.text: And if you speak of the Spirit, you name also God the Father, from Whom the Spirit proceeds, and the Son, inasmuch as He is also the Spirit of the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:40
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:41
verses.text: Wherefore that authority may also be joined to reason Scripture indicates that we can also be rightly baptized in the Spirit, when the Lord says: "But ye shall be baptized in the Holy Spirit".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:42
verses.text: And in another place the Apostle says: "For we were all baptized in the body itself into one Spirit".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:43
verses.text: The work is one, for the mystery is one; the baptism one, for there was one death on behalf of the world; there is, then, a oneness of working, a oneness of setting forth, which cannot be separated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:44
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:45
verses.text: But if in this place the Spirit be separated from the operation of the Father and the Son, because it is said, All things are of God, and all things are through the Son, then, too, when the Apostle says of Christ, "Who is over all, God blessed for ever," He set Christ not only above all creatures, but (which it is impious to say) above the Father also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:46
verses.text: But God forbid, for the Father is not amongst all things, is not amongst a kind of crowd of His own creatures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:47
verses.text: The whole creation is below, over all is the Godhead of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:48
verses.text: The former serves, the latter rules; the former is subject, the latter reigns; the former is the work, the latter the author of the work; the former, without exception, worships, the latter is worshipped by all without exception.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:49
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:50
verses.text: Lastly, of the Son it is written: "And let all the angels of God worship Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:51
verses.text: You do not find, Let the Holy Spirit worship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:52
verses.text: And farther on: "To which of the angels said He at any time, Sit thou on My right hand till I make thine enemies the footstool of thy feet? Are they not all," says he, "ministering spirits who are sent to minister?" When he says All, does he include the Holy Spirit? Certainly not, because Angels and the other Powers are destined to serve in ministering and obedience to the Son of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:53
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:54
verses.text: But in truth the Holy Spirit is not a minister but a witness of the Son, as the Son Himself said of Him: "He shall bear witness of Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:55
verses.text: The Spirit, then, is a witness of the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:56
verses.text: He who is a witness knows all things, as God the Father is a witness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:57
verses.text: For so you read in later passages, for our salvation was confirmed to us by God bearing witness by signs and wonders and by manifold powers and by distributions of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:58
verses.text: He who divides as he will is certainly above all, not amongst all, for to divide is the gift of the worker, not an innate part of the work itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:59
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:60
verses.text: If the Son is above all, through Whom our salvation received its commencement, so that it might be preached, certainly God the Father also, Who testifies and gives confirmation concerning our salvation by signs and wonders, is excepted from all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:61
verses.text: In like manner the Spirit, Who bears witness to our salvation by His diversities of gifts, is not to be numbered with the crowd of creatures, but to be reckoned with the Father and the Son; Who, when He divides, is not Himself divided by cutting off Himself, for being indivisible He loses nothing when He gives to all, as also the Son, when the Father receives the kingdom, loses nothing, nor does the Father, when He gives that which is His to the Son, suffer loss.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:62
verses.text: We know, then, by the testimony of the Son that there is no loss in the division of spiritual grace; for He Who breathes where He wills is everywhere free from loss.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:63
verses.text: Concerning which power we shall speak more fully farther on.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:64
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:65
verses.text: In the meanwhile, since our intention is to prove in due order that the Spirit is not to be reckoned amongst all things, let us take the Apostle, whose words they call in question, as an authority for this position.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:66
verses.text: For what "all things" would be, whether visible or invisible, he himself declared when he said: "For in Him were all things created in the heavens and in earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:67
verses.text: You see that "all things" is spoken of things in the heavens, and of things in earth, for in  the heavens are also invisible things which were made.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:68
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:69
verses.text: But that no one should be ignorant of this he added those of whom he was speaking: "Whether thrones or dominions or principalities or powers, all things were created by Him and in Him, and He is before all, and in Him all things consist".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:70
verses.text: Does he, then, include the Holy Spirit here amongst creatures? Or when he says that the Son of God is before all things, is he to be supposed to have said that He is before the Father? Certainly not; for as here he says that all things were created by the Son, and that all things in the heavens consist in Him, so, too, it cannot be doubted that all things in the heavens have their strength in the Holy Spirit, since we read: "By the word of the Lord were the heavens established and all the strength of them by the Spirit of His mouth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:71
verses.text: He, then, is above all, from Whom is all the strength of things in heaven and things on earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:72
verses.text: He, then, Who is above all things certainly does not serve; He Who serves not is free; He Who is free has the prerogative of lordship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:73
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:74
verses.text: If I were to say this at first it would be denied.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:75
verses.text: But in the same manner as they deny the less that the greater may not be believed, so let us set forth lesser matters first that either they may show their perfidy in lesser matters, or, if they grant the lesser matters, we may infer greater from the lesser.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:76
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:77
verses.text: I think, most merciful Emperor, that they are most fully confuted who dare to reckon the Holy Spirit amongst all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:78
verses.text: But that they may know that they are pressed not only by the testimony of the apostles, but also by that of our Lord; how can they dare to reckon the Holy Spirit amongst all things, since the Lord Himself said: "He who shall blaspheme against the Son of Man, it shall be forgiven him; but he who shall blaspheme against the Holy Ghost shall never be forgiven, either here or hereafter".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:79
verses.text: How, then, can any one dare to reckon the Holy Spirit amongst creatures? Or who will so blind himself as to think that if he have injured any creature he cannot be forgiven in any wise? For if the Jews because they worshipped the host of heaven were deprived of divine protection, whilst he who worships and confesses the Holy Spirit is accepted of God, but he who confesses Him not is convicted of sacrilege without forgiveness: certainly it follows from this that the Holy Spirit cannot be reckoned amongst all things, but that He is above all things, an offence against Whom is avenged by eternal punishment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:80
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:81
verses.text: But observe carefully why the Lord said: "He who shall blaspheme against the Son of Man it shall be forgiven him, but he who shall blaspheme against the Holy Ghost shall never be forgiven, either here or hereafter".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:82
verses.text: Is an offence against the Son different from one against the Holy Spirit? For as their dignity is one, and common to both, so too is the offence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:83
verses.text: But if any one, led astray by the visible human body, should think somewhat more remissly than is fitting concerning the Body of Christ (for it ought not to appear of little worth to us, seeing it is the palace of chastity, and the fruit of the Virgin), he incurs guilt, but he is not shut out from pardon, which he may attain to by faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 3:84
verses.text: But if any one should deny the dignity, majesty, and eternal power of the Holy Spirit, and should think that devils are cast out not in the Spirit of God, but in Beelzebub, there can be no attaining of pardon there where is the fulness of sacrilege; for he who has denied the Spirit has denied also the Father and the Son, since the same is the Spirit of God Who is the Spirit of Christ.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:2
verses.text: The Holy Spirit is one and the same Who spake in the prophets and apostles, Who is the Spirit of God and of Christ; Whom, further, Scripture designates the Paraclete, and the Spirit of life and truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:3
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:4
verses.text: But no one will doubt that the Spirit is one, although very many have doubted whether God be one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:5
verses.text: For many heretics have said that the God of the Old Testament is one, and the God of the New Testament is another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:6
verses.text: But as the Father is one Who both spake of old, as we read, to the fathers by the prophets, and to us in the last days by His Son; "and as the Son is one, Who according to the tenour of the Old Testament was offended by Adam, seen by Abraham, worshipped by Jacob; so, too, the Holy Spirit is one, who energized in the prophets, was breathed upon the apostles, and was joined to the Father and the Son in the sacrament of baptism.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:7
verses.text: For David says of Him: "And take not Thy Holy Spirit from me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:8
verses.text: And in another place he said of Him: "Whither shall I go from Thy Spirit?"  56.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:9
verses.text: That you may know that the Spirit of God is the same as the Holy Spirit, as we read also in the Apostle: "No one speaking in the Spirit of God says Anathema to Jesus and no one can say, Lord Jesus, but in the Holy Spirit," the Apostle calls Him the Spirit of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:10
verses.text: He called Him also the Spirit of Christ, as you read: "But ye are not in the flesh but in the Spirit, if so be that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:11
verses.text: And farther on: "But if the Spirit of Him Who raised Jesus from the dead dwelleth in you".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:12
verses.text: The same is, then, the Spirit of God, Who is the Spirit of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:13
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:14
verses.text: The same is also the Spirit of Life, as the Apostle says: "For the law of the Spirit of Life in Christ Jesus hath delivered me from the law of sin and death".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:15
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:16
verses.text: Him, then, Whom the Apostle called the Spirit of Life, the Lord in the Gospel named the Paraclete, and the Spirit of Truth, as you find: "And I will ask the Father, and He will give you another Comforter [Paraclete], that He may be with you for ever, even the Spirit of Truth, Whom this world cannot receive; because it seeth Him not, neither knoweth Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:17
verses.text: You have, then, the Paraclete Spirit, called also the Spirit of Truth, and the invisible Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:18
verses.text: How, then, do some think that the Son is visible in His Divine Nature, when the world cannot see even the Spirit?  59.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:19
verses.text: Receive now the saying of the Lord, that the same is the Holy Spirit Who is the Spirit of Truth, for you read in the end of this book: "Receive the Holy Spirit".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:20
verses.text: And Peter teaches that the same is the Holy Spirit Who is the Spirit of the Lord, when he says: "Ananias, why has it seemed good to thee to tempt and to lie to the Holy Spirit?" And immediately after he says again to the wife of Ananias: "Why has it seemed good to you to tempt the Spirit of the Lord?" When he says "to you," he shows that he is speaking of the same Spirit of Whom he had spoken to Ananias.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:21
verses.text: He Himself is, then, the Spirit of the Lord Who is the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:22
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:23
verses.text: And the Lord Himself made clear that the same Who is the Spirit of the Father is the Holy Spirit, when according to Matthew He said that we ought not to take thought in persecution what we should say: "For it is not ye that speak, but the Spirit of your Father that speaketh in you".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:24
verses.text: Again He says according to St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:25
verses.text: Luke: "Be not anxious how ye shall answer or speak, for the Holy Spirit of God shall teach you in that hour what ye ought to say".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:26
verses.text: So, although many are called spirits, as it is said: "Who maketh His Angels spirits," yet the Spirit of God is but one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:27
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 4:28
verses.text: Both apostles and prophets received that one Spirit, as the vessel of election, the Doctor of the Gentiles, says: "For we have all drunk of one Spirit;" Him, as it were, Who cannot be divided, but is poured into souls, and flows into the senses, that He may quench the burning of this world's thirst.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:2
verses.text: The Holy Spirit, since He sanctifies creatures, is neither a creature nor subject to change.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:3
verses.text: He is always good, since He is given by the Father and the Son; neither is He to be numbered amongst such things as are said to fail.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:4
verses.text: He must be acknowledged as the source of goodness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:5
verses.text: The Spirit of God's mouth, the amender of evils, and Himself good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:6
verses.text: Lastly, as He is said in Scripture to be good, and is joined to the Father and the Son in baptism, He cannot possibly be denied to be good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:7
verses.text: He is not, however, said to progress, but to be made perfect in goodness, which distinguishes Him from all creatures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:8
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:9
verses.text: The Holy Spirit is not, then, of the substance of things corporeal, for He sheds incorporeal grace on corporeal things; nor, again, is He of the substance of invisible creatures, for they receive His sanctification, and through Him are superior to the other works of the universe.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:10
verses.text: Whether you speak of Angels, or Dominions, or Powers, every creature waits for the grace of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:11
verses.text: For as we are children through the Spirit, because "God sent the Spirit of His Son into our hearts crying, Abba, Father; so that thou art now not a servant but a son;" in like manner, also, every creature is waiting for the revelation of the sons of God, whom in truth the grace of the Holy Spirit made sons of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:12
verses.text: Therefore, also, every creature itself shall be changed by the revelation of the grace of the Spirit, "and shall be delivered from the bondage of corruption into the liberty of the glory of the children of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:13
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:14
verses.text: Every creature, then, is subject to change, not only such as has been changed by some sin or condition of the outward elements, but also such as can be liable to corruption by a fault of nature, though by careful discipline it be not yet so; for, as we have shown in a former treatise, the nature of Angels evidently can be changed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:15
verses.text: It is certainly fitting to judge that such as is  the nature of one, such also is that of others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:16
verses.text: The nature of the rest, then, is capable of change, but the discipline is better.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:17
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:18
verses.text: Every creature, therefore, is capable of change, but the Holy Spirit is good and not capable of change, nor can He be changed by any fault, Who does away the faults of all and pardons their sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:19
verses.text: How, then, is He capable of change, Who by sanctifying works in others a change to grace, but is not changed Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:20
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:21
verses.text: How is He capable of change Who is always good? For the Holy Spirit, through Whom the things that are good are ministered to us, is never evil.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:22
verses.text: Whence two evangelists in one and the same place, in words in differing from each other, have made the same statement, for you read in Matthew: "If you, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children; how much more shall your Father, Who is in heaven, give good things to them that ask Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:23
verses.text: But according to Luke you will find it thus written: "How much more shall your heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to them that ask Him?" We observe, then, that the Holy Spirit is good in the Lord's judgment by the testimony of the evangelists, since the one has put good things in the place of the Holy Spirit, the other has named the Holy Spirit in the place of good things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:24
verses.text: If, then, the Holy Spirit is that which is good, how is He not good?  66.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:25
verses.text: Nor does it escape our notice that some copies have likewise, according to St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:26
verses.text: Luke: "How much more shall your heavenly Father give a good gift to them that ask Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:27
verses.text: This good gift is the grace of the Spirit, which the Lord Jesus shed forth from heaven, after having been fixed to the gibbet of the cross, returning with the triumphal spoils of death deprived of its power, as you find it written: "Ascending up on high He led captivity captive, and gave good gifts to men".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:28
verses.text: And well does he say "gifts," for as the Son was given, of Whom it is written: "Unto us a Child is born, unto us a Son is given;" so, too, is the grace of the Spirit given.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:29
verses.text: But why should I hesitate to say that the Holy Spirit also is given to us, since it is written: "The love of God is shed forth in our hearts by the Holy Spirit, Who is given to us".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:30
verses.text: And since captive breasts certainly could not receive Him, the Lord Jesus first led captivity captive, that our affections being set free, He might pour forth the gift of divine grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:31
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:32
verses.text: And He said well "led captivity captive".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:33
verses.text: For the victory of Christ is the victory of liberty, which won grace for all, and inflicted wrong on none.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:34
verses.text: So in the setting free of all no one is captive.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:35
verses.text: And because in the time of the Lord's passion wrong alone had no part, which had made captive all of whom it had gained possession, captivity itself turning back upon itself was made captive, not now attached to Belial but to Christ, to serve Whom is liberty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:36
verses.text: "For he who is called in the Lord as a servant is the Lord's freedman".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:37
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:38
verses.text: But to return to the point.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:39
verses.text: "All," says He, "have gone aside, all together are become unprofitable.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:40
verses.text: There is none that doeth good, not even one".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:41
verses.text: If they except the Holy Spirit, even they themselves confess that He is not amongst all; if they do not except Him, then they, too, acknowledge that He has gone aside amongst all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:42
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:43
verses.text: But let us consider whether He has goodness in Himself, since He is the Source and Principle of goodness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:44
verses.text: For as the Father and the Son have, so too the Holy Spirit also has goodness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:45
verses.text: And the Apostle also taught this when he said: "Now the fruit of the Spirit is peace, love, joy, patience, goodness".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:46
verses.text: For who doubts that He is good Whose fruit is goodness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:47
verses.text: For "a good tree brings forth good fruit".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:48
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:49
verses.text: And so if God be good, how shall He Who is the Spirit of His mouth not be good, Who searcheth even the deep things of God? Can the infection of evil enter into the deep things of God? And from this it is seen how foolish they are who deny that the Son of God is good, when they cannot deny that the Spirit of Christ is good, of Whom the Son of God says: "Therefore said I that He shall receive of Mine".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:50
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:51
verses.text: Or is the Spirit not good, Who of the worst makes good men, does away sin, destroys evil, shuts out crime, pours in good gifts, makes apostles of persecutors, and priests of sinners? "Ye were," it is said, "sometime darkness, but now are ye light in the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:52
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:53
verses.text: But why do we put them off? And if they ask for statements since they do not deny facts, let them hear that the Holy Spirit is good, for David said: "Let Thy good Spirit lead me forth in the right way".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:54
verses.text: For what is the Spirit but full of goodness? Who though because of His nature He cannot be attained to, yet because of His goodness  can be received by us, filling all things His power, but only partaken of by the just, simple in substance, rich in virtues, present to each, dividing of His own to every one, and Himself whole everywhere.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:55
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:56
verses.text: And with good cause did the Son of God say: "Go and baptize all nations in the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit," not disdaining association with the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:57
verses.text: Why, then, do some take it ill that He Whom the Lord disdained not in the sacrament of baptism, should be joined in our devotion with the Father and the Son?  74.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:58
verses.text: Good, then, is the Spirit, but good, not as though acquiring but as imparting goodness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:59
verses.text: For the Holy Spirit does not receive from creatures but is received; as also He is not sanctified but sanctifies; for the creature is sanctified, but the Holy Spirit sanctifies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:60
verses.text: In which matter, though the word is used in common, there is a difference in the nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:61
verses.text: For both the man who receives and God Who gives sanctity are called holy, as we read: "Be ye holy, for I am holy".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:62
verses.text: Now sanctification and corruption cannot share the same nature, and therefore the grace of the Holy Spirit and the creature cannot be of one substance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:63
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:64
verses.text: Since, then, the whole invisible creation (whose substance some rightly believe to be reasonable and incorporeal), with the exception of the Trinity, does not impart but acquires the grace of the Spirit, and does not share in it but receives it, the whole commonalty of creation is to be separated from association with the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 5:65
verses.text: Let them then believe that the Holy Spirit is not a creature; or, if they think Him a creature, why do they associate Him with the Father? If they think Him a creature, why do they join Him with the Son of God? But if they do not think that He should be separated from the Father and the Son, they do not consider Him to be a creature, for where the sanctification is one the nature is one.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:2
verses.text: Although we are baptized with water and the Spirit, the latter is much superior to the former, and is not therefore to be separated from the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:3
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:4
verses.text: There are, however, many who, because we are baptized with water and the Spirit, think that there is no difference in the offices of water and the Spirit, and therefore think that they do not differ in nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:5
verses.text: Nor do they observe that we are buried in the element of water that we may rise again renewed by the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:6
verses.text: For in the water is the representation of death, in the Spirit is the pledge of life, that the body of sin may die through the water, which encloses the body as it were in a kind of tomb, that we, by the power of the Spirit, may be renewed from the death of sin, being born again in God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:7
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:8
verses.text: And so these three witnesses are one, as John said: "The water, the blood, and the Spirit".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:9
verses.text: One in the mystery, not in nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:10
verses.text: The water, then, is a witness of burial, the blood is a witness of death, the Spirit is a witness of life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:11
verses.text: If, then, there be any grace in the water, it is not from the nature of water, but from the presence of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:12
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:13
verses.text: Do we live in the water or in the Spirit? Are we sealed in the water or in the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:14
verses.text: For in Him we live and He Himself is the earnest of our inheritance, as the Apostle says, writing to the Ephesians: "In Whom believing ye were sealed with the Holy Spirit of promise, Who is an earnest of our inheritance".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:15
verses.text: So we were sealed by the Holy Spirit, not by nature, but by God, for it is written: "He Who anointed us is God, Who also sealed us, and gave the earnest of the Spirit in our hearts".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:16
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:17
verses.text: We were then sealed with the Spirit by God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:18
verses.text: For as we die in Christ, in order to be born again, so, too, we are sealed with the Spirit, that we may possess His brightness and image and grace, which is undoubtedly our spiritual seal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:19
verses.text: For although we were visibly sealed in our bodies, we are in truth sealed in our hearts, that the Holy Spirit may portray in us the likeness of the heavenly image.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:20
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:21
verses.text: Who, then, can dare to say that the Holy Spirit is separated from the Father and the Son, since through Him we attain to the image and likeness of God, and through Him, as the Apostle Peter says, are partakers of the divine nature? In which there is certainly not the inheritance of carnal succession, but the spiritual connection of the grace of adoption.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 6:22
verses.text: And in order that we may know that this seal is rather on our hearts than on our bodies, the prophet says: "The light of Thy countenance has been impressed upon us, O Lord, Thou hast put gladness in my heart".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:2
verses.text: The Holy Spirit is not a creature, seeing that He is infinite, and was shed upon the apostles dispersed through all countries, and moreover sanctifies the Angels also, to whom He makes us equal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:3
verses.text: Mary was full of the same likewise, so too, Christ the Lord, and so far all things high and low.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:4
verses.text: And all benediction has its origin from His operation, as was signified in the moving of the water at Bethesda.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:5
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:6
verses.text: Since then, every creature is confined within certain limits of its own nature, and inasmuch as those invisible operations, which cannot be circumscribed by place and bounds, yet are closed in by the property of their own substance; how can any one dare to call the Holy Spirit a creature, Who has not a limited and circumscribed power? because He is always in all things and everywhere, which assuredly is the property of Divinity and Lordship, for: "The earth is the Lord's and the fulness thereof".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:7
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:8
verses.text: And so, when the Lord appointed His servants the apostles, that we might recognize that the creature was one thing and the grace of the Spirit another, He appointed them to different places, because all could not be everywhere at once.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:9
verses.text: But He gave the Holy Spirit to all, to shed upon the apostles though separated the gift of indivisible grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:10
verses.text: The persons, then, were different, but the accomplishment of the working was in all one, because the Holy Spirit is one of Whom it is said: "Ye shall receive power, even the Holy Spirit coming upon you, and ye shall be witnesses to Me in Jerusalem and in all Judea and Samaria, and unto the ends of the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:11
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:12
verses.text: The Holy Spirit, then, is uncircumscribed and infinite, Who infused Himself into the minds of the disciples throughout the separate divisions of distant regions, and the remote bounds of the whole world, Whom nothing is able to escape or to deceive.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:13
verses.text: And therefore holy David says: "Whither shall I go from Thy Spirit, or whither shall I flee from Thy face".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:14
verses.text: Of what Angel does the Scripture say this? of what Dominion? of what Power? of what Angel do we find the power diffused over many? For Angels were sent to few, but the Holy Spirit was poured upon whole peoples.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:15
verses.text: Who, then, can doubt that that is divine which is shed upon many at once and is not seen; but that that is corporeal which is seen and held by individuals?  83.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:16
verses.text: But in like manner as the Spirit sanctifying the apostles is not a partaker of human nature; so, too, He sanctifying Angels, Dominions, and Powers, has no partnership with creatures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:17
verses.text: But if any think that the holiness of the Angels is not spiritual, but some other kind of grace belonging to the property of their nature, they will forsooth judge Angels to be inferior to men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:18
verses.text: For since themselves also confess that they would not dare to compare Angels to the Holy Spirit, and they cannot deny that the Holy Spirit is shed upon men; but the sanctification of the Spirit is a divine gift and favour, men who possess a better kind of sanctification will certainly be found to be preferred to the Angels.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:19
verses.text: But since Angels come down to men to assist them, it must be understood that the nature of Angels is higher as it receives more of the grace of the Spirit, and that the favour awarded to us and to them comes from the same author.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:20
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:21
verses.text: But how great is that grace which makes even the lower nature of the lot of men equal to the gifts received by Angels, as the Lord Himself promised, saying: "Ye shall be as the Angels in heaven".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:22
verses.text: Nor is it difficult, for He Who made those Angels in the Spirit will by the same grace make men also equal to the Angels.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:23
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:24
verses.text: But of what creature can it be said that it fills all things, as is written of the Holy Spirit: "I will pour My Spirit upon all flesh".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:25
verses.text: This cannot be said of an Angel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:26
verses.text: Lastly, Gabriel himself, when sent to Mary, said: "Hail, full of grace," plainly declaring the grace of the Spirit which was in her, because the Holy Spirit had come upon her, and she was about to have her womb full of grace with the heavenly Word.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:27
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:28
verses.text: For it is of the Lord to fill all things, Who says: "I fill heaven and earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:29
verses.text: If, then, it is the Lord Who fills heaven and earth, Who can judge the Holy Spirit to be without a share in the dominion and divine power, seeing that He has filled the world, and what is beyond the whole world, filled Jesus the Redeemer of the whole world? For it is written: "But Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, departed from Jordan".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:30
verses.text: Who, then, except one who possessed the same fulness could fill Him Who fills all things?  87.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:31
verses.text: But lest they should object that this was said according to the flesh, though He alone from Whose flesh went forth virtue to heal all, was more than all; yet, as the Lord fills all things, so, too, we read of the Spirit: "For the Spirit of the Lord filled the whole world".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:32
verses.text: And you find it said of all  who had consorted with the Apostles that, "filled with the Holy Spirit they spoke the word of God with boldness".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:33
verses.text: You see that the Spirit gives both fulness and boldness, Whose operation the archangel announces to Mary, saying: "The Holy Spirit shall come on thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:34
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:35
verses.text: You read, too, in the Gospel that the Angel descended at the appointed time into the pool and troubled the water, and he who first went down into the pool was made whole.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:36
verses.text: What did the Angel declare in this type but the descent of the Holy Spirit, which was to come to pass in our day, and should consecrate the waters when invoked by the prayers of the priest? That Angel, then, was a herald of the Holy Spirit, inasmuch as by means of the grace of the Spirit medicine was to be applied to our infirmities of soul and mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:37
verses.text: The Spirit, then, has the same ministers as God the Father and Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:38
verses.text: He fills all things, possesses all things, works all and in all in the same manner as God the Father and the Son work.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:39
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book I 7:40
verses.text: What, then, is more divine than the working of the Holy Spirit, since God Himself testifies that the Holy Spirit presides over His blessings, saying: "I will put My Spirit upon thy seed and My blessings upon thy children".
